title: GARFIELD-AF Risk Score
description: The GARFIELD-AF risk score simultaneously predicts 1- and 2-year risks of mortality, ischemic stroke/systemic embolism, and major bleeding in patients with atrial fibrillation. This contemporary risk stratification tool incorporates 16 clinical variables and has been validated across diverse international populations with both anticoagulated and non-anticoagulated patients.

parameters.name: pulse
parameters.description: Heart rate in beats per minute

parameters.name: heart_failure
parameters.description: History of heart failure or reduced ejection fraction

parameters.name: history_of_stroke
parameters.description: History of stroke or transient ischemic attack

parameters.name: chronic_kidney_disease
parameters.description: Chronic kidney disease or renal impairment

parameters.name: vascular_disease
parameters.description: Vascular disease (coronary artery disease, peripheral arterial disease, or aortic plaque)

parameters.name: dementia
parameters.description: History of dementia or cognitive impairment

parameters.name: antiplatelet_use
parameters.description: Current use of antiplatelet medications (aspirin, clopidogrel, etc.)

result.name: risk_predictions
result.description: Multi-outcome risk predictions for mortality, stroke/systemic embolism, and major bleeding at 1 and 2 years

ranges.interpretation: Low risk for mortality, stroke/systemic embolism, and major bleeding. Standard anticoagulation management appropriate if indicated for stroke prevention.
Moderate risk profile. Consider individualized approach to anticoagulation with careful monitoring. Regular follow-up recommended.

High risk profile across multiple outcomes. Requires intensive management, frequent monitoring, and careful consideration of anticoagulation benefits versus bleeding risks. Consider specialist consultation.

references: Fox KAA, Lucas JE, Pieper KS, et al. Improved risk stratification of patients with atrial fibrillation: an integrated GARFIELD-AF tool for the prediction of mortality, stroke and bleed in patients with and without anticoagulation. BMJ Open. 2017;7(12):e017157. doi: 10.1136/bmjopen-2017-017157.

Apenteng PN, Murray ET, Holder R, et al. An international longitudinal registry of patients with atrial fibrillation at risk of stroke: Global Anticoagulant Registry in the FIELD (GARFIELD). Am Heart J. 2012;163(1):13-19.e1. doi: 10.1016/j.ahj.2011.09.011.
Camm AJ, Accetta G, Ambrosio G, et al. Evolving antithrombotic treatment patterns for patients with newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation. Heart. 2017;103(4):307-314. doi: 10.1136/heartjnl-2016-309832.
formula: Complex regression model with 16 variables predicting simultaneous risks of mortality, ischemic stroke/systemic embolism, and major bleeding at 1 and 2 years using validated coefficients from GARFIELD-AF registry
notes: The GARFIELD-AF score simultaneously predicts three key outcomes: mortality, ischemic stroke/systemic embolism, and major bleeding
Risk predictions are provided for both 1-year and 2-year time horizons
The score has been validated in both anticoagulated and non-anticoagulated patients
This tool incorporates contemporary clinical variables and is based on a large international registry
Unlike single-outcome scores (CHA2DS2-VASc, HAS-BLED), GARFIELD-AF provides integrated risk assessment
The score helps balance anticoagulation benefits against bleeding risks in individual patients
Regular re-evaluation is recommended as clinical status changes may affect risk predictions
